content.title: Pelvic Congestion Syndrome
content.summary: Chronic pelvic pain caused by ovarian and pelvic venous insufficiency with varices, occurring predominantly in premenopausal multiparous women.

definitions.definition: Chronic pelvic pain (>6 months) caused by dilated, incompetent ovarian and pelvic veins, often associated with visible vulvar or thigh varices.
Retrograde flow in the ovarian veins due to absent or incompetent valves, leading to venous engorgement of pelvic organs.

key_concepts.explanation: Dull, aching pelvic pain worse with standing and premenstrual. Associated with dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, urinary urgency, and visible vulvar or thigh varices (communicating with saphenous system).

Transvaginal ultrasound shows dilated pelvic veins (>5-6mm). Ovarian venography (gold standard) demonstrates reflux and varices. MR venography provides non-invasive assessment. CT may show dilated veins incidentally.

Catheter-based embolization of incompetent ovarian and internal iliac tributaries using coils, foam sclerosant, or both. Bilateral treatment often needed. 70-80% experience significant symptom relief.
Pelvic varices can communicate with leg varicose veins via escape points (vulvar, obturator, gluteal). Treatment of pelvic source may be necessary for recurrent leg varices.

evidence.citation: Beard et al., Randomized Trial of Embolization, 1998
evidence.finding: Ovarian vein embolization reduced pain scores by 50% in 83% of patients at 1-year follow-up
Technical success rate >95% with embolization; major complications <5%

clinical_pearls: PCS is a diagnosis of exclusion - rule out gynecologic, GI, and urologic causes
Symptoms often worse in the second half of menstrual cycle due to hormonal effects
Vulvar or medial thigh varices in a multiparous woman strongly suggest pelvic source
May coexist with May-Thurner syndrome - evaluate for iliac compression
Recurrent leg varices after stripping may have pelvic origin
learning_objectives: Recognize clinical features suggesting pelvic congestion syndrome
Describe diagnostic imaging findings in PCS
Explain the technique of ovarian vein embolization
Identify the relationship between pelvic and lower extremity varices
